text: hey everyone its mark Wiens with
migration ology calm and eating Thai
food calm I'm in Bangkok Thailand and
I'm going to very quickly show you how
to make the recipe for Kokua which is
toasted sticky rice powder it's a very
important ingredient for many Thai Isan
dishes and when you make it fresh
yourself it just tastes delicious and
gives the dishes that it uses a
beautiful roasted fragrance okay you
want a medium heat put on your wok or
frying pan okay once your pan is hot
we're going with just this is just
normal Thai sticky rice goes in and this
is probably about a cup but you can make
however much you want and then you're
just going to basically dry roast it for
about 15 minutes
continually stirring it's starting to
smell extremely good it smells like
popcorn about ready it's been about 10
or 15 minutes and it's turning yellow
golden almost like wheat so I'm about to
turn off the fire right now just put it
right back into that bowl and next step
I'm just going to pound it into a coarse
powder whole that's hot but it is
extremely fragrant actually I should
probably use a spoon transfer it
directly into the mortar and pestle and
I am just going to pound that into a
coarse powder and in about five minutes
we'll have perfect fresh cow kuat to
cook with
ok we are done that's it for making
Kokua it is an essential ingredient in
many Isan dishes like lab and num buck
and also many different dipping sauces
it gives food kind of a smoky roasted
flavor as well as a crunchy texture and
I guarantee that if you make it fresh
yourself it's going to give your dishes
an extra edge or an extra dimension of
delicious flavor that you're going to
love
